text:
If your Shopify inventory syncs with NetSuite on a schedule, you're overselling. 
You just haven't caught it yet.

Most e-commerce teams I talk to sync inventory every 15-30 minutes. During normal volume, nobody notices. A few units off, maybe. Nothing urgent.

During a flash sale or peak season, that 15-minute gap means:
- Customers order products that are already gone
- Your warehouse cancels orders after the fact
- Customers get a refund email instead of a shipping confirmation
- Reviews drop. Trust drops. CAC goes up.

The root cause is the latency between your storefront and your ERP. When Shopify shows "12 units in stock" and NetSuite shows "0 units in stock," both systems are telling the truth. About different moments in time. 

Overselling lives in that gap.

Real-time sync closes it. When a unit sells in Shopify, NetSuite reflects it in seconds. 

When warehouse receives new stock, Shopify updates live. 

No schedule. No 15-minute window where your storefront is lying to customers.

If you're running Shopify + NetSuite and you've ever had to send a "sorry, we oversold" email, the sync delay is probably why.

DMs are open.

resharedPost/text:
Every line on the left is a point of failure.


Every line is a maintenance ticket. A rate limit. A 3am Slack alert.

Mid-market companies are running 10-15 integrations across their stack:
- Salesforce
- NetSuite
- Shopify
- Snowflake 

And stitching them together with 3-4 different tools that were never designed to talk to each other.

The result? 

Your data engineers spend 60% of their time babysitting pipelines instead of building product.

The Stacksync approach: one sync layer. Bidirectional. Real-time. Every system reads and writes through a single source of truth.

And one more thing:Enterprise level AI its comming to Stacksync too. :)

text:
38,000+ companies run NetSuite. Most of them also run Salesforce. Almost none of them have real-time sync between the two.
If your company uses both, this is what your Monday morning looks like:

Sales closes a deal in Salesforce on Friday. Finance doesn't see it in NetSuite until Monday's batch sync runs. Could be hours late. Could be a full business day.

An invoice gets updated in NetSuite. The sales team is still quoting off yesterday's numbers. The customer gets two different answers from two different teams at the same company.

Revenue meetings turn into reconciliation sessions. Someone pulls a report from Salesforce. Someone else pulls one from NetSuite. The numbers don't match. Half the meeting is spent figuring out which system is right.

Then engineering gets pulled in. "Can you check why this record didn't sync?" That question turns into a morning of debugging. Then a recurring ticket. Then it's just part of someone's job description.

The pattern:
- Sales and finance work from different versions of the truth
- Deals get invoiced late because data moves in batches
- Customer-facing teams quote stale numbers
- Engineers maintain the connection instead of building product

Most companies accept this as normal. Buy middleware. Build custom code. Live with batch jobs. 
All three add complexity. None give you data that moves when it changes.

The alternative: put NetSuite data in a database your team can query directly. 
No batch windows. No stale numbers. Data moves the moment it changes.

That's what we do at Stacksync. NetSuite to Postgres. Always current. Both directions.

If this sounds like your Monday, DMs are open.

text:
If you're a Salesforce shop with a Postgres database, Heroku Connect might be the most important tool you've never heard of.
Salesforce just ended sales for it. Here's what it does and why it matters:

What Heroku Connect does:
Your company uses Salesforce. Your engineering team needs that data in a database to build product, run reports, power features.

Normal way: build a custom API integration. Authentication. Pagination. Rate limits. Retry logic. Maintenance. Forever.

Heroku Connect way: Salesforce data appears in Postgres tables. 

Automatically. Both directions. Engineers query it with SQL. No API code.
The team that built it proved something important: SQL is a better interface to CRM data than APIs. Dozens of lines of API code vs a few lines of SQL. Same result.

They launched it in 2014. They were ahead of their time.

On February 6, Salesforce ended new Heroku Enterprise sales. End of Sale. Maintenance only.
What that means if you're on Heroku Connect:

- No new features coming
- Bugs stay as-is
- Locked to Heroku Postgres only (no AWS, no Cloud SQL, no Supabase)
- $4K/month and up depending on Salesforce instance size
- Your database and your sync tied to a platform with no roadmap

What that means if you're NOT on it:
The pattern Heroku Connect proved is the right architecture. If your engineers are writing custom Salesforce API code in 2026, there's a better way. And the team that proved it deserved more support than they got.

At Stacksync, we build on that pattern. Real-time sync. Any Postgres. 60-70% less cost.

If this is new to you, DMs are open. Happy to walk through what a Salesforce-to-Postgres sync looks like for your team.

text:
2011: Salesforce pays $212M. Calls it "the future of cloud computing."
2026: End of Sale. "Sustaining engineering mode."

They took what they needed. Then moved on.

The question isn't whether to migrate.

It's whether you migrate on your timeline or theirs.

At Stacksync, we connect to any Postgres. Heroku, Railway, Render, self-hosted.

Your data layer shouldn't depend on one vendor's AI strategy.

Credits on the image: Mikel Lindsaar

text:
A $100M+ coffee brand and the  #1 EDI platform backed by a16z joined us (Stacksync)

Not for a conference. For a NetSuite event we threw at Fellow's office in SF.

Good people, good food, and good times.

Arvind Jeyakumar from Fellow showed how they built their data infrastructure scaling to nine-figure revenue. 

Fellow sells in Target, Costco,Nordstrom. All running through NetSuite.

Blake Harries from Orderful went deep on what modern EDI looks like when you have 10,000+ trading partners and 500M+ transactions behind you. 

Our CEO Ruben Burdin showed what Stacksync has been doing to pave the way in AI, integrations, and EDI.

All of them were masterclass presentations.

Awesome to meet everyone who came out and also see some familiar faces.

Huge shoutout to Fellow for letting us throw a party in their office.

First event had 15 people. This one had 45. Next one is going to be bigger.

 See you all at the next one.

resharedPost/text:
A $100M coffee brand, An a16z-backed EDI platform & A real-time sync engine.
Three companies that shouldn't have anything in common.

Except NetSuite.
And the scars from scaling on it.

Feb 4th— Fellow, Orderful, and Stacksync in one room. San Francisco.

Here's who's talking:

🎙️Arvind Jeyakumar — Head of Data at Fellow

Fellow got rejected by investors 73 times.
Bootstrapped for 8 years.
Now they're past $100M in revenue—selling in Target, Costco, and Nordstrom.

Arvind built the data infrastructure that made that scale possible. 

🎙️Blake Harries — Senior Channel Manager at Orderful.

Orderful is a16z-backed and just launched Mosaic—the first product to kill manual EDI mapping entirely.

Liquid Death. Faherty. Some of the fastest-moving brands run their partner onboarding through Orderful. 4x faster. Zero manual mapping.

Blake will share how they're solving the connectivity headaches NetSuite users know too well.

👤 And Stacksync?

We're the ones who figured out real-time, bi-directional sync between NetSuite and everything else. No more batch jobs. No more stale data. No more waiting until tomorrow.

Different products.
Different industries.
Same ERP battles.
Same lessons worth sharing.

Details:

📆 Date: February 4th
📍 Location: Fellow HQ Offices, 320 Florida Street, San Francisco, 94115.
🚗 Parking: Mission Bartlett Garage (3251 21st St) or 16th Street BART

Spots are limited to keep the conversation high-signal.

Link to RSVP in the comments.
See you there.
text: Three companies that refused to lose, one room, and probably the best NetSuite war stories you'll hear all year.

resharedPost/text:
The NetSuite Signal is lit over San Francisco! 🌉

In the era of AI-driven operations, the ultimate competitive advantage isn't just the ERP you use—it's how fast you can connect it to the rest of your ecosystem.

Join the SF NetSuite User Group for an exclusive evening of high-stakes conversation. 

We’re moving past the "AI hype" to discuss the actual infrastructure required to make AI-native enterprise automation a reality.


🎙️ The Lineup

Arvind Jeyakumar — Head of Data at Fellow. Fellow was rejected 73 times and bootstrapped for 8 years before crossing $100M. Arvind built the data infrastructure that made that legendary scale possible.

Blake Harries — Senior Channel Manager at Orderful. The a16z-backed company that just killed manual EDI mapping. Liquid Death and Faherty are already using it to onboard partners 4x faster. 

Ruben Burdin— CEO at Stacksync. Sharing the latest on the Stacksync <> NetSuite integration, the bridge between your data and your growth.

✨ The Experience

The "NetSuite + AI" Roadmap: Raw insights on building an "Intelligent Stack" without the "integration tax."

Top-Shelf Hospitality: Chilled Champagne, gourmet savory bites, and decadent desserts.

Elite Networking: Connect with SF’s top NetSuite admins, developers, and finance leaders.

📍 Logistics & Arrival
Venue: Fellow Coffee/HQ, 820 Valencia Street, San Francisco.
Parking: We highly recommend the Mission Bartlett Garage (3251 21st St) or the 16th Street BART Garage for a seamless arrival.

A special thanks to Joshua Meiri for his support and collaboration on this.

RSVP: Headcount is strictly limited to ensure high-value networking.
Secure your spot, link in comments👇
text: Champagne AND desserts AND a conversation about killing integration debt? This is the SF event equivalent of having your cake and syncing it too.

text:
3 AM.
Slack alert: "API rate limit exceeded. Sync failed."

You know what comes next.

Roll out of bed. Open laptop. Check which batch job hit the limit this time. Manually restart. Hope it doesn't happen again in 2 hours.

Our clients had this exact night more times than I can count.

The worst part? It's not even their fault.

They did everything right:
- Implemented exponential backoff
- Batched requests efficiently
- Scheduled jobs during off-peak hours

But Salesforce doesn't care. HubSpot doesn't care. 
The rate limit exists to protect their infrastructure, not yours.

So you set your alarm. You build monitoring. You create runbooks for failures that shouldn't happen.

You become an integration babysitter instead of an engineer.

This is what we refused to accept when building Stacksync.

Our architecture doesn't hammer APIs with batch requests. 

It listens for changes and syncs events, not bulk queries. We've processed millions of records for customers without hitting a single rate limit.

No 3 AM alerts. No manual restarts. No babysitting.

If you're waking up to rate limit errors, you're not the problem.

Your integration architecture is.

resharedPost/text:
$70 billion in one day.
That was Snowflake's market cap when the bell rang in 2020. Largest software IPO in history.

The CEO who led it? Frank Slootman.
The same Frank Slootman who took ServiceNow public in 2012 for $2 billion.

Two companies. Two industries. Same person at the helm when it mattered most.

But the founders are the real story.

Fred Luddy started ServiceNow at 50. 

After losing $35 million overnight to fraud at his previous company. 
Everyone thought he was done.

Nine months after swearing he'd never touch IT service management again, he started building. Today that company is worth $150 billion.

Dageville and Cruanes started Snowflake after 16 years at Oracle. 
They bet against Hadoop when everyone in the industry said Hadoop was the future.

Two years arguing over whiteboards in San Mateo. No funding announcements. No hype. Just conviction that the cloud could do what on-premise never could.

Both founders built something real. Both needed an operator who could see it and scale it.

Both found Slootman.

If you work at ServiceNow: you're part of a comeback story that started in a 50-year-old's worst moment.

If you work at Snowflake: you're part of the company that proved an entire industry wrong.

Founders build what operators can't imagine.
Operators scale what founders can't reach.
That's the pattern. Twice.

---
Snowflake proved it for data warehousing. 
ServiceNow proved it for workflows. 

The next frontier?

Real-time sync between your CRM and ERP. That's what we're building at Stacksync.
text: There is the "second-time founder", but the real flex is "two-times IPO" CEO. Impressive.

text:
We tested every Salesforce integration tool on the market
Fivetran. Airbyte. Stitch. Heroku Connect. Workato. Celigo.
Same pattern every time: 

batch windows, polling intervals, or locked into one ecosystem.

But what if you need:

▪️Sub-second sync, not "near real-time" that's actually 5-15 minutes
▪️Updates that bypass API rate limits entirely (because you're querying Postgres, not Salesforce)
▪️Your own database, anywhere—not vendor lock-in

None of these tools were built for that.
So we built Stacksync.

This is the feedback we've got:

🎖️Acertus migrated from Heroku Connect: "We went from treating data integration as a necessary evil that consumed our best engineers to having it just work."

🎖️Nautilus Solar replaced legacy pipelines: "Error-free sync with custom object support—our team can focus on growth, not maintenance."

🎖️Eko eliminated CRM integration headaches: "Stacksync makes my problem disappear. This investment is pure ROI."

The difference between polling every 15 minutes and syncing in milliseconds is the difference between a report and a live system.

One shows you what happened. 
The other lets you act on it.

Want to see the Salesforce two-way sync in action?
Link in the comments.

comments/3/text:
Totally get the frustration. A lot of teams bounce between tools expecting a different outcome and end up disappointed.

That said, iPaaS itself is not the issue. Using integration as a narrow sync layer is.

Fast, SQL first, bi directional sync is great for certain problems. It does not replace orchestration, governance, error handling, security, or complex workflows that show up the moment you scale.

Most teams are not stuck because of the logo they chose. They are stuck because integration strategy gets fragmented and point tools pile up. 

Most important part will be moving from iPaaS to a dynamic platform that handles integration  automation, api management, data management, and then operational Ai that can be used in real use cases.

text:
MuleSoft. Workato. Boomi.
Three different logos. Same fundamental problem.

They were all built for a world where:

▪️Integration was a project, not a product
▪️Engineers expected to write custom code
▪️"Real-time" meant "pretty fast eventually"
▪️Complexity justified six-figure contracts

That world is dying.

Here's what they all share:

1. Task-based or connector-based pricing that punishes growth
2. "Bi-directional" that's actually polling intervals and batch jobs stitched together
3. Implementation timelines measured in months
4. Platforms that require specialized talent just to connect to your existing stack

You can switch from MuleSoft to Workato.
You'll have the same problems with a different support team.

You can migrate from Workato to Boomi.
Different strengths on paper. Same latency in practice. Different invoice.

The problem isn't which iPaaS you choose.
The problem might be iPaaS itself.

We built Stacksync from first principles.

✅ It replaces: your iPaaS, your EDI provider. your reverse ETL, your event queues, your fragile sync scripts.
✅ True bi-directional sync. Sub-second latency. SQL-first.
✅ Pricing based on records, not tasks.

We didn't mean to replace that many tools.
Customers just kept asking.

If you've been vendor-hopping between the big three and wondering why nothing improves, now you know.

Same problem. Different logo.

text:
After 20 years in sales, hundreds of deals.
I noticed one pattern:
The reps who chase, lose.

"Just checking in!"
"Wanted to bump this up!"
"Any update?"

That's not follow-up. That's hope.

What works:

Set a timeline on the call.

Both sides agree: "On this date, we reconnect."

If they reschedule or don't show?

One question: "What's changed?"

That question does more than your entire email sequence.

It surfaces the real objection.
It shows mutual respect.
It separates live deals from dead ones.

Same with your data.

If your reps spend Monday mornings asking "which number is right?"—they're not selling, they're reconciling.

When CRM and database sync in real-time, the only question left is "What's changed?" with the customer.

Not with the spreadsheet.

Wanna know more?


Tony B.

text:
The definition of a successful company: 
Create more value for customers than it captures for itself. 

That's it. Everything else is commentary.

If you create value, customers pay you. If enough customers pay you, you're profitable. 

If you're profitable, you're creating more than you're extracting. That's the proof.

Funding is not proof. It's a bet that proof will come later.
Press is not proof. It's attention that may or may not convert to anything.
Awards are not proof. They're opinions from people who don't use your product.

Customer expansion is proof. It means you solved something real and they want more of it.

I've been running this company long enough to know: the only metric that compounds is customer value. 
Everything else is noise that fades.

At Stacksync we're not waiting to become successful. 
We've been operating at the standard that creates it.
The labels arrive when they arrive.

resharedPost/text:
Why is HubSpot our most popular connector? 


We asked ourselves this a few months ago.
We had some theories but did not exactly know why.

So we did something simple:

I went into the HubSpot Community and started answering questions.
Not promoting and not selling, just helping.

One question became five, then fifty then five hundred.

2 weeks ago I got a badge notification: Problem Solver (500)

Only 22 people in the world have it. But the badge wasn't the point.

Every answer showed us something we'd missed.

Frustrations sometimes we miss in customer calls.

I went in to learn. 

We came out understanding our customers better than ever.

Go where they're already struggling and help. 

Thanks: HubSpot Community :)
text: This is why I joined Stacksync: Customer obsession.

resharedPost/text:
OpenAI just broke ground on an AI campus larger than the Pentagon.
I had to re-read that twice.

Project Stargate. 

Rural Texas. $25 billion. Oracle and Vantage building it.

The scale is absurd:

1,200 acres = 2.5x Monaco 
3.7 million sq ft = Pentagon-sized 
1.4 gigawatts = one nuclear reactor 
250kW per rack = 5x hotter than Google's data centers

That last number matters. 

At 250kW density, you can't air-cool anymore. 
The physics don't work. Liquid cooling is the only option.

San Francisco uses 900 megawatts at peak demand. 

This one campus will pull 1,400.
First building goes live H2 2026. 

They're building a second one in Wisconsin

Sam Altman isn't racing Anthropic anymore
He's racing the Texas power grid
text:
The infrastructure story gets all the attention, but the harder problem is what happens when you try to actually feed these systems. 

At this scale, data pipelines and source system integrations become the bottleneck, most enterprises can't move their data fast enough to keep up with what the compute layer can consume.

At Stacksync - Integration Cloud we can help you with that.

text:
109 million customer records
AT&T lost them in 2024, but nobody broke through a firewall:

Attackers used a stolen password to log into a cloud account that had no extra verification turned on. That's it.

Ticketmaster and Santander, same story. Credentials sitting in tools that nobody was watching.

I talk to companies every day at Stacksync about how they connect their systems. 

CRM to database or ERP to warehouse. 

Every one of those connections needs a password. 

And most companies have no idea how many of those passwords exist, where they live, or who has access to them.

Your team changes their passwords every few months, but the password that connects Salesforce to your database? 

That one's been the same since 2019.
Attackers know this. 

We built Stacksync knowing this too, these certifications weren't optional for us

resharedPost/text:
Some teams hit Kafka limits and ask: “How do we make Kafka faster?”
At OpenAI scale, the question was different:

“How do we make Kafka less central?”

Kafka stopped being the front door

Producers no longer talked to brokers directly
A proxy layer absorbed retries, spikes, and bad client behavior
Kafka became the durable backbone and not the place where chaos lands

The result (publicly reported):

 – ~20× higher throughput
 – Five-nines availability
 – Regions that fail without taking each other down

Why it worked:

 – Brokers stopped handling unbounded client behavior
 – Backpressure was intentional instead of emergent
 – Failure handling moved out of the core

The lesson:
If something is both critical and central, it will cap your scale.

Don’t just scale the component.
Move the blast radius.

And be honest about the cost: more moving parts, new failure modes, and more operational work.

That’s what real scale looks like.
text:
What I like about this framing is the honesty about tradeoffs. 

More abstraction layers mean more moving parts and new failure modes. 

But when the alternative is your core system absorbing every spike and bad behavior from upstream, the complexity is worth it. 

We think about this a lot at Stacksync - Integration Cloud. 

The goal isn't eliminating moving parts, it's putting them in the right places.

resharedPost/text:
8 databases.
That's all Supabase had in April 2020.

COVID everywhere. Two founders. One startup that nobody wanted.
Paul Copplestone stared at the dashboard.
Four months of building. 8 people using it.

But he'd been here before: 

15 years earlier, he pitched this same idea to a millionaire in New Zealand.
One word back: "No."

Now he was 15 years older, stuck in a pandemic YC batch, watching the same story repeat.

Nobody cared.
Then he saw it.

Developers on Hacker News. Complaining about Firebase. The same frustrations, over and over.

"Vendor lock-in." 
"No real alternative." 
"Why doesn't something open-source exist?"

Paul looked at his website.
It said: "realtime Postgres."
Accurate. Technical. Dead.
He deleted it.

Typed five new words:
"The Open-Source Firebase Alternative."
Same product. Different story.
He hit post.

72 hours later: 800 databases.

One of the biggest developer tool launches Hacker News had ever seen.

Paul wasn't sleeping. Ant wasn't sleeping. Servers melting.
It worked.

But here's where most founders blow it.

The money came. Enterprise contracts. Millions waiting.
Paul said no.

"If we take this now, we become a services company. We stop building the thing."

Ant looked at him. They had nothing. This was real money.
Paul didn't blink.

"We're not building a consulting firm. We're building the biggest database company in the world."

They stayed in beta.
For four years.

Today:
$0 → $70M ARR 
8 → 4 million databases 
Nothing → $5B Valuation

Their slogan: "Build in a weekend. Scale to millions."
Paul built the idea in a weekend.
But took him 15 years to become the person who could see it through.

The slogan wasn't marketing.
It was autobiography.
text: 8 to 800 databases in 3 days. Not because they shipped new features, but because they reframed the problem. Counter-positioning against an incumbent people already have opinions about is so underrated. We think about this constantly at Stacksync. It's not just about being better, it's about being the obvious alternative.
